data.title: Famous People Born in 1903
data.meta_description: Celebrate the birthdays of 430 famous people, historical figures and celebrities born in 1903 like Lou Gehrig, John Dillinger and Tunku Abdul Rahman.
data.text:
Birthdays 1 - 200 of 430

Anton van Duinkerken [Willem Jan Marie Anton Asselbergs], Dutch poet and academic, born in Bergen op Zoom, Netherlands (d. 1968)

Jan 2 Kane Tanaka, Japanese centenarian (world's 2nd oldest recorded person), born in Wajiro Village, Japan (d. 2022)

Charles Foulkes, Canada general and honorary citizen of Wageningen who accepted WWII Germany's surrender in the Netherlands, born in Stockton-on-Tees, England, (d. 1969)

Joris Diels, Flemish actor and director (It's a Cruel World, Haagsche Comedy), born in Antwerpen, Belgium (d. 1992)

Harold Gatty, Australian aviator, navigator with Wiley Post, born in Campbell Town, Australia (d. 1957)

Jan 5 Leighton Lucas, English composer and conductor, born in London, England (d. 1982)

Boris Blacher, German composer (Orchester-Ornament), born in Yingkou, China (d. 1975)

Jan 6 Francis L. Sullivan, British actor (Great Expectations, Oliver Twist, Missing Rembrandt), born in London, England (d. 1956)

Jan 6 Maurice Abravanel, American classical music conductor, born in Thessaloniki, Greece (d. 1993)

Jan 6 Stanley Smith, American actor and singer (King of Jazz; Soup to Nuts; Good News), born in Kansas City, Missouri (d. 1974)

Alan Napier, British actor (The Sword in the Stone, Batman), born in Birmingham, England (d. 1988)

Jan 7 Albrecht Haushofer, German geographer and writer, born in Munich, Germany (d. 1903)

Jan 9 Hem Vejakorn, Thai illustrator, born in Bangkok, Thailand (d. 1969)

Barbara Hepworth, English abstract artist, sculptor and child actress (Rescued by Rover), born in Wakefield, West Riding of Yorkshire (d. 1975)

Alan Paton

South African author (Cry, the Beloved Country, Too Late the Phalarope) and anti-apartheid activist, born in Pietermaritzburg, South Africa

Igor Kurchatov, Soviet-Russian nuclear physicist who directed the Soviet atomic bomb project, born in Sim, Chelyabinsk Oblast, Russia (d. 1960)

Jyoti Prasad Agarwala, Assamese poet, playwright, filmmaker (d. 1953)

Jan 17 Warren Hull, American actor (Strike it Rich, Who in the World), born in Gasport, New York (d. 1974)

Jan 18 Berthold Goldschmidt, German-British opera composer (Beatrice Cenci), born in Hamburg, German Empire (d. 1996)

Alfred Beit, British politician and art philanthropist, born in London, England (d. 1994)

Leon Ames, American actor (Mister Ed, Father of the Bride), born in Portland, Indiana (d. 1993)

G. Evelyn Hutchinson, British zoologist (Treatise on Limnology), born in Cambridge, United Kingdom (d. 1991)

Gardner Cowles Jr., American publisher (Look Magazine)t, born in Algona, Iowa (d. 1985)

Carl Reynolds, American baseball outfielder who was 2nd player in MLB history to hit HRs in 3 consecutive innings 1930; Chicago White Sox, born in LaRue, Texas (d. 1978)

Feb 1 Georg Rendl, Austrian miner, beekeeper and writer (The Bees Novel) (d. 1972)

Frank McGrath, American actor (The Reluctant Astronaut, Wagon Train), born in Mound City, Missouri (d. 1967)

Kay Boyle, American novelist (Plagued by Nightingales), born in St. Paul, Minnesota (d. 1992)

Feb 19 Sadiq Hidajat, Persian writer (Blind Person Owl), (d. 1951)

Feb 20 Karel Janeček, Czech composer and pedagogue, born in Czestochowa, Czechoslovakia (d. 1974)

Feb 20 Pierre Charles, Belgian heavyweight boxer, born in Heer Agimont, Namur, Belgium (d. 1966)

Anaïs Nin, French-Cuban writer (Delta of Venus), born in Neuilly-sur-Seine, France (d. 1977)

Feb 21 Eric Fogg, English composer, born in Manchester, England (d. 1939)

Feb 21 Raymond Queneau [M Presle], French author (Un Enfant a Dit), born in La Havre, France (d. 1976)

Ain-Ervin Mere, Estonian Nazi (d. 1969)

Frank Ramsey

British mathematician and philosopher, born in Cambridge, United Kingdom

Feb 22 Morley Callaghan, Canadian author and radio personality (Toronto Star, Native Argosy), born in Toronto, Ontario (d. 1990)

King Clancy, Canadian ice hockey player (d. 1986)

Italian chemist and Nobel laureate, born in Imperia, Italy

Grethe Weiser, German actress (The Great Love), born in Hanover, Lower Saxony, Germany (d. 1970)

Vincente Minnelli, director (An American in Paris, Gigi), born in Chicago, Illinois (d. 1986)

Gilbert Adrian [Greenberg], American costume designer (MGM films, The Wizard of Oz), born in Naugatuck, Connecticut (d. 1959)

Maud Lewis (née Dowley), Canadian folk artist and painter, born in South Ohio, Nova Scotia (d. 1970)

(Leon Bismarck) "Bix" Beiderbecke, American jazz cornetist, considered one of the most influential jazz soloists of the 1920s, pianist, and composer (In A Mist), born in Davenport, Iowa (d. 1931)

Dorothy Schiff, American owner and publisher (NY Post), born in New York City (d. 1989)

American inventor who created silica, born in Solvay, New York

Joy Ridderhof, American missionary (d. 1984)

Thomas Pitfield, British composer, born in Bolton, England (d. 1999)

Harold Edgerton, American electrical engineer and photographer who created high-speed photography techniques, born in Fremont, Nebraska (d. 1990)

Mickey Cochrane

American Baseball HOF catcher (MLB All-Star 1934, 35; World Series 1929, 30, 35; AL MVP 1928, 34; Philadelphia A's, Detroit Tigers) and manager (Detroit Tigers 1934–38), born in Bridgewater, Massachusetts
